Can you write a hypothetical alternate plot for the manga Gate JSDF, only in this version the US military, the Philippine military and the South Korean military arr invited to join into the other world with the JSDF, and the US military is represented by the Rat Patrol ftom Metal Gear Solid 4 lead by Meryl Silverburgh accompanied by Old Snake and Otacon, the Philippine military comprises the cast of 2003's Philippine comedy Asboobs Asal Bobo which comprises of an ice cream vendor was bullied and thrown on a river and he swore to become a brave soldier, joining him include a spoiled brat snaps his adopted uncle and forced him to undergo military training, a barangay tanod or a neighborhood watchman in thecPhilippine language who is an action freak who mauled even the well wishers for his birthday, a NEET who accidentally burned a whole building while he was in an internet cafe and was offered to be a soldier by his roommate and a mama's boy who joins the military to strengthen his manhood and erase his mama's boy image, and the South Korean military comprises adult versions of the cast of the manhwa Girls of the Wild’s including the manhwa’s characters Jaeoh Hwang, Yeojoeung Kim, and Gangrok Choi since conscription in South Korea is mandatory, making it some crossover, how would their interactions be with Itami Tomita, Kuribayashi and the rest of the JSDF? And their interactions with the empire especially with Princess Pina and Prince Zorzal, Rory, Yao, Lelei and Tuka, and the scenarios? How do they play out in these episodes: 1"The Self-Defence Force Goes to Another World"
A mysterious gate suddenly appears in Ginza, Tokyo, through which mythological creatures led by men in Roman armor emerge and attack the people. Yōji Itami, a JSDF reservist who is attending a nearby doujin convention, helps organizing the police to evacuate the civilians to the Imperial Palace before the JSDF arrives to stop the invaders. For his actions, Itami is promoted to First Lieutenant and celebrated as a national hero. The appearance of the Gate and attack on Japanese civilians, dubbed the Ginza Incident, prompts the incumbent Prime Minister to take action by proclaiming that Japan will send a JSDF task force backed by the US to the "Special Region", the world beyond the Gate, to not only explore the new world but also capture and demand reparations from those responsible for the attack. After three months of preparation, the new Prime Minister sends off the JSDF task force, including Itami, on their mission to the Special Region. Upon arriving, the task force encounters an army waiting for them, and prepares for battle.
2"Two Military Forces"
The army sent by the Empire to deal with the Japanese forces stationed at Alnus Hill, where the Gate is located, is easily obliterated by the JSDF's modern artillery. Emperor Molt calls for the armies of the Empire's vassal states to attack, only for them to be defeated with massive casualties as well; a move planned by the Emperor to prevent the vassal states from taking advantage of the Empire's depleted military. While Emperor Molt decides to delay a possible advance from the JSDF, Itami is assigned to lead the 3rd Recon Unit, created to survey the nearby cities and points of interest. After passing by the village of Coda, the 3rd Unit observes a massive Fire Dragon burning and destroying a settlement within the nearby forest. While looking for survivors, Itami finds an unconscious Elf woman inside a well.
3"Fire Dragon"
Taking the Elf with them, the 3rd Unit return to the village of Coda, and upon learning of the Fire Dragon, the villagers decide to evacuate, assisted by the Japanese soldiers. The group, now including all the villagers, are later joined by two mages, Lelei la Lalena and her master Kato El Altestan. Hoping to take advantage of the situation, a group of bandits decide to attack the villagers, only to be slaughtered by Rory Mercury, an apostle of the Dark God Emroy. While escorting the refugees, Itami's party encounter Rory, who decides to accompany them as well. However, the Fire Dragon appears and attacks the convoy, killing numerous villagers until the 3rd Unit blows off one of its front legs with an anti-tank rocket, forcing it to retreat. After the 3rd Unit parts ways with the villagers, Itami decides to take the remaining refugees, as well as Rory, the Elf woman, and Lelei, back to Alnus Hill. 

4"To Unknown Lands"
The 3rd Recon Unit returns to Alnus Hill, now converted into an advanced JSDF base, and Itami obtains authorization to provide shelter to the refugees. Meanwhile, Princess Piña Co Lada from the Empire learns more about the JSDF's exploits and decides to investigate them personally. Back at Alnus, the refugees get used to their new lives among the Japanese soldiers, but for some reason Tuka Luna Marceau, the Elf girl, keeps requesting supplies not only for herself, but for another, unknown male not listed among the guests. Knowing that they cannot depend on the JSDF's charity forever, Lelei points out that they can collect scales from the corpses of dragons killed by JSDF, which will fetch a good price in the local markets. Meanwhile, on the other side of the gate, the Japanese Diet requests Itami for an audience regarding the battle against the Fire Dragon. However, by the time the summons for Itami arrives, he has already left with Rory, Lelei, Tuka and the rest of the 3rd Unit to trade the collected dragon scales at the city of Italica, where Piña and her Knights are also headed in search of further information about the JSDF.
5"The Battle of Italica"
Itami's party arrives at Italica, just as the city's forces, led by Princess Piña, repel an assault by an invading bandit force made up of deserters from the armies defeated at Alnus. Knowing that her knights and the local militia lack the strength to keep holding off the bandits until help arrives, Piña finds herself in a predicament until she meets the 3rd Recon Unit. Upon being informed of the situation, Itami decides to help defend the city and agrees with Piña's plan of positioning himself and his soldiers on the least guarded side of the walls (the South Gate) to act as a decoy. However, the enemy does not fall for their trap and launches an attack on the main force at the East Gate instead. As the city's defenses are broken, the Princess finds herself on the verge of despair. 

6"Ride of the Valkyries"
Rory, Itami and two of his subordinates, Akira Tomita and Shino Kuribayashi, head to Piña's location to help her men. Meanwhile, the JSDF sends a helicopter unit to assist the 3rd Recon Unit in defending Italica, which arrives just in time, blasting Wagner's Ride of the Valkyries from loudspeakers and annihilating the invaders with ease. After Lelei sells the dragon scales and Itami has negotiated with Piña and the Italicans for rather trivial compensation terms in exchange for their retaining their sovereignty, the 3rd Recon Unit departs back to Alnus Hill, only to encounter Piña's Order of the Rose Knights on their way. Upon discovering their identities as JSDF members, the knights take Itami captive, unaware of the peace treaty he and Piña just established. In order to avoid further conflict, Itami orders his unit to leave without him instead of fighting, leaving himself at the knights' mercy. 

7"The Princess's Decision"
Back in Italica, Piña reprimands her knights Bozes and Panache for capturing Itami, fearing that the JSDF will use the incident as an excuse to retaliate for breaking the treaty. As the Formal family staff treat Itami's wounds, Rory, Lelei, Tuka and some of the 3rd Unit sneak back to Italica to rescue Itami, but find themselves welcomed by the Formal maids and join Itami for a small socializing party. Meanwhile, Piña orders Bozes to sleep with Itami in the hopes of earning his forgiveness, but Bozes becomes angry and assaults Itami after seeing him enjoying himself and seemingly ignoring her. Appalled that Bozes might have antagonized Itami further, Piña and Bozes join the 3rd Recon Unit's trip back to Alnus Hill to personally apologize to Itami's superiors for Bozes' actions. While Piña and Bozes meet with Itami's commanding officer Lieutenant General Hazama with Lelei as an interpreter, Itami invites Tuka to come with him to Japan to meet the Japanese Diet as a representative of the Special Region. The next day, Itami, Shino and Akira accompany Rory, Lelei, Tuka, Piña and Bozes through the Gate to Japan.
8"Japan, Beyond the Gate"
Itami and his group arrive in Tokyo, where Piña and the others girls are awed by the city and its people. After meeting a Public Security agent by the name of Komakado, Itami, Rory, Lelei, and Tuka head to the Japanese Diet while Piña and Bozes meet with members of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to discuss the details for the upcoming peace talks. At the Japanese Diet, Itami, Rory, Lelei, and Tuka are questioned by the chairwoman of the Investigation Committee on the Fire Dragon attack, who accuses the JSDF of failing to protect the refugees killed by the Fire Dragon. Rory, Lelei, and Tuka defend the JSDF, telling of how the Japanese soldiers helped save many lives from the monster. Afterwards, both Itami's and Piña's groups reunite in the subway to escape from the press as well as a mysterious group which seems to be targeting the Special Region girls. Due to a mole leaking their itinerary, Itami makes a change of plans and brings the group to stay with his ex-wife.
9"The Hakone Mountain Night Battle"
Itami explains everything to his ex-wife Risa, who agrees to help him by taking Rory, Lelei and Tuka on a shopping trip the next day, while Akira accompanies Piña and Bozes to the library after both of them take an interest in boys-love manga from Risa. Meanwhile, Itami meets with his old friend, Defense Minister Kanou Tarou, who instructs him to bring the Special Region guests to a hot spring inn guarded by the Japanese SFG. As Itami's group stays at the inn for some relaxation, three different Black Ops teams enter the area and battle with the SFG. While the SFG identifies two of the Black Ops operatives as Americans, the Japanese Prime Minister is blackmailed by the US President, who wants the SFG to stop attacking his Black Ops team so they can take the Special Region guests with them. The Prime Minister orders Tarou to tell his men to stand down, but not before revealing that he will be resigning to void the President's leverage. As the three Ops teams head to the Inn, Itami encounters a drunken and aroused Rory. 

10"Despair and Hope"
Rory's attempts to seduce Itami are interrupted by a phone call from Tarou. The US Black Ops team arrives at the Inn, only to encounter the two rival teams from Russia and China, leading to a three-way firefight which Rory soon joins, ending with everyone besides Rory dead. After taking a van from the Russians, Itami's group heads back to Ginza, but, worried that the foreign agents will attack again, Risa posts a message on the internet that the Special Region girls will be visiting the Ginza memorial. As a result, a large crowd gathers at Ginza to meet the girls, hindering the foreign agents' plans to kidnap them. Public Security is able to inconspicuously arrest all foreign agents on the scene, and after Shino publicizes the previous kidnapping attempts on live TV through her news reporter sister Nanami, the US, Chinese, and Russian leaders cancel the kidnapping operation. After saying goodbye to Risa and paying their respects at the Ginza memorial, the Special Region girls return to the Gate. Realizing the Empire's war with Japan will lead to its destruction, Piña makes plans to head back to the Capital to arrange peace talks between both sides.
11"Visitor"
Five months since the Gate's opening, the Alnus refugee camp has developed into a town and trading center for goods from Earth. At the Imperial capital, Piña introduces Kouji Sugawara, the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs' new ambassador to the Empire, to Lord Cicero, one of the most important nobles within the Empire's pro-war faction, and obtains his cooperation with the peace talks in exchange for the release of his nephew, who is currently in Japan's custody as a POW. Back in Alnus, Tuka keeps wandering the city looking for her father and refusing to accept the fact that he is already dead. As Itami and his friends discuss their concern for Tuka in a tavern, Kurokawa claims that they must make her face the truth, but Itami objects, certain that they can not be responsible for Tuka forever. Left alone with Rory, Itami keeps drinking with her until a Dark Elf woman by the name of Yao Haa Dushi appears and, mistaking Rory for a child, reprimands Itami for giving her alcohol. With her plans to spend the night with Itami ruined, an annoyed Rory mischievously plays along with the Dark Elf's misunderstanding, forcing Itami to flee. The Elf is unaware that Itami was one of the "Men in Green" she was looking for, whom she wants to ask for aid for her people, who are attacked by the Fire Dragon. The next day, as she prepares to visit the JSDF's base at Alnus, Itami heads towards the Imperial capital.
12"What Would Itami Do"
Yao's initial attempts to ask the JSDF for help fail, as most of the soldiers know little of the local language, and she is arrested by the Military Police after attacking several thugs who mistake her for a prostitute. Lelei, having improved her magic thanks to Earth's advanced scientific knowledge, is called by the JSDF to serve as Yao's interpreter. After learning her story, General Hazama tells Yao that he cannot help her, as her home, Schwartz Forest, is located in the Elbe Kingdom, which is outside the borders of the Empire. As the Japanese are currently in peace talks with the Empire, sending troops over their border would mean a declaration of war and reignite conflict. With Yao devastated at the news, some soldiers sympathize with her, and Lieutenant Akira Yanagida suggests that Yao should ask Itami for help. Elsewhere, Itami and his men deliver goods from Earth to Piña and Hamilton, as part of their plan to win over more nobles to seek peace with Japan. Before leaving, Itami gives Piña a Yaoi doujin translated by Bozes and Panache, which, unknown to him, contains newspaper clippings of his previous heroic actions. As Itami heads back to base hoping to achieve peace between both sides, Lelei narrates that the war is far from over.
13"The Banquet Begins"
In the Imperial Capital, a private party hosted by Piña is attended by a group of Senators and their families led by Lord Cicero, who, after seeing the 3rd Recon's weapons demonstrations, realizes the futility of fighting the Japanese and seeks to negotiate for peace. However, Crown Prince Zorzal, Piña's elder brother, learns of the meeting and rides with his entourage to confront the senators for treason. Itami's scouts spot the prince approaching, and the 3rd Recon helps the senators escape undetected before he arrives. At Akusho, the capital's red light district, Mari joins the JSDF team stationed there, using her training as a nurse to aid the locals who show up at the outpost. Meanwhile, Yao tries to learn about the people that are important to Itami from a local, while Itami, Shino and Akira stay at Pina's palace. Back at the Akusho outpost, the demi-human prostitutes warn Mari that they feel an "Earth-Shake" is coming. Recognizing it as a sign similar to how animals on Earth can detect earthquakes before they occur, Nyuutabaru, the commanding officer at the outpost, warns the soldiers in the Special Region to evacuate the civilians before the earthquake begins. 

14"The Imperial Capital Quake"
Piña invites Sugawara, Itami, Shino and Akira to meet with her father the Emperor in the Imperial Palace to advise them how to handle earthquakes. However, Zorzal also arrives to warn his father of another earthquake foretold by his slave Noriko, who is to Piña and the Japanese delegates' shock revealed as a Japanese citizen. Angered with Zorzal's cruel treatment of Noriko, Itami punches him and rescues the girl. Zorzal's bodyguards try to attack, only to be gunned down by Shino, and Itami and Shino torture Zorzal for information about other Japanese captives, only to be stopped by Tyuule, Zorzal's other slave. Sugawara warns the Emperor there will be repercussions if the kidnapped Japanese citizens are not returned to the Japanese before leaving, and the Japanese launch an air strike at the Imperial Senate building as a further message to make peace. While Tyuule treats Zorzal wounds, Zorzal younger brother, Diabo, learns their father wants to make Zorzal his heir, as he believes that he can easily control Zorzal from the shadows once he abdicates. Meanwhile, Noriko arrives at the JSDF Alnus base, hoping to return to Japan, unaware that her parents were killed during the Ginza incident. Elsewhere, Tuka continues to fruitlessly search for her father.
15"Tuka Luna Marceau"
At the Imperial capital, Diabo and Piña learn that Zorzal has been officially made heir to the throne and, aware of his father's plans, won't become his father's puppet. Unknown to them, Zorzal is being manipulated by Tyuule, who seeks revenge against the Empire and plans its destruction by the JSDF by having Noriko killed and Piña framed for it. At Alnus, Yanagida asks Itami to head to the Elbe Kingdom to kill the Fire Dragon, but Itami refuses as he won't endanger his soldier's lives. However, Tuka has gone insane and now believes Itami is her father after Yao forced her to face the fact that her father was killed by the Fire Dragon. Confronted, Yao reveals that she is desperate for Itami's help to save her people, even if it means hurting those close to him. Itami pretends to be Tuka's father for the time being, but Tuka still continues to slip further into madness. After having a talk with the disguised King Duran of Elbe, who is recuperating at Alnus, Itami finally decides to help Tuka confront and take revenge against the Fire Dragon, which will end her delusions. Rather than going to the Imperial capital with his men, Itami departs with Tuka, Rory, Lelei and Yao in a Humvee with supplies provided by Yanagida.
16"The Fire Dragon, Once More"
Delilah, the Warrior Bunny who works at the bar at Alnus refugee town, receives orders from her masters, the Formal Clan, that she is to assassinate Noriko, which, unknown to her, were actually forged by Tyuule, the former Queen of her tribe. When General Hazama learns of Itami's quest to Elbe, he forms a task force to help him fight the Fire Dragon, and Yanagida and King Duran make a deal to allow the JSDF to cross the Elbe Kingdom. Delilah attempts to kill Noriko fails when Yanagida discovers them, which ends with both of them injured fighting each other. The JSDF investigates the assassination attempt and, with help from the Formal Clan, learns the Formal Clan butler forged the letter under orders from Zorzal's faction, and to gain more information, one of Itami's soldiers, Furuta Hitoshi, goes undercover as a chef in the Capital, where he gains Zorzal's favor. Meanwhile, Itami's party finally reaches Yao's village. While Yao goes to greet her people, Itami and the others are surrounded by a group of Dark Elf guards, only for the Fire Dragon to appear. 

17"Decisive Battle"
After driving the Fire Dragon off and meeting the elders of the Dark Elves, Itami and his group heads to the Fire Dragon's nest in the mountains with a group of Dark Elf volunteers. With Rory guarding the entrance of the nest, Itami and his group install a fragmentation bomb beneath the Fire Dragon's nest using C4 and magic weapons lying around to kill the Fire Dragon by surprise. However, the Fire Dragon arrives and kills most of the Dark Elves. As the battle rages, Tuka finally accepts that her father is dead, and uses lighting magic, which ignites the C4, killing the Fire Dragon. As the survivors escape from the mountain, they find Rory heavily injured after fighting Giselle, a rival apostle. Giselle reveals she was the one that woke the Fire Dragon, which led to its rampage, as she was using the Fire Dragon's two hatchlings as help to capture Rory for her patron, the underworld goddess Hardy. Giselle's dragons chase after Itami and his group, only for the JSDF task force to arrive and kill the dragons, forcing Giselle to retreat.
18"The Magic City of Rondel"
Itami is punished for going AWOL fighting the Fire Dragon, but is right afterwards rewarded by various people for his heroic actions and given a new mission to scout for resources with Lelei, Rory, Tuka and Yao. The group heads to the Magic City of Rondel, where Lelei plans to hold a presentation to her fellow mages which, if successful, will gain her the rank of Master, and where they encounter Lelei's older sister Arpeggio and her mentor Mimoza La Mer. Meanwhile in the Imperial Capital, peace talks between Japan and the Empire officially begin, much to Zorzal's anger since the assassination attempt on Noriko and framing it on Pina have failed to derail it. As everyone celebrates the Fire Dragon's death, the Emperor is pleased to learn that Lelei, an Imperial citizen, was also involved in helping defeat the dragon. However, the Emperor suddenly falls ill after drinking wine, secretly poisoned under Tyuule's orders. 

19"Dangerous Sisters"
With the Emperor bedridden, Zorzal takes over the throne and declares his intent to avenge the Empire's humiliation by the Japanese. With the Imperial capital in curfew, the JSDF forces in Akusho are trapped and the Japanese Ambassadors put under house arrest. To Piña's anger, Zorzal has the pro-peace faction arrested and has his loyal followers planning to attack the Japanese with unconventional and unethical tactics, and her other brother Diabo has run away to seek help from other, superior forces to overthrow Zorzal. Meanwhile in Rondel, Mimoza reveals something interesting to Itami and the others about the Gate: Every few centuries or millenniums, the Gods of the Special Region would open a portal (the Gate) to another world at Alnus, through which the races of those worlds would come and settle in, explaining why they are many different types of races living here. When Arpeggio angrily learns that Lelei has outachieved her in any conceivable field (including finding a romantic interest with Itami), the sisters have a magic duel to settle their dispute. An assassin tries to kill Lelei at the end of the match but is eliminated by Grey. Grey and another Rose Knight, Shandy, reveal to Itami and his group that the assassin was sent by Zorzal due to his jealousy of Lelei's fame of defeating the Flame Dragon, and the two of them came to protect them under Piña's orders. Rather than stay and fight, however, Itami decides that it's best they run away from the assassins.
20"Lover"
As Itami and his group continue to evade Zorzal's killers, Zorzal's secret police continue to arrest the pro-peace faction for treason throughout the capital. Despite this, the Japanese are ordered by their government to not get involved, including refusing sanctuary for the pro-peace faction. Marquess Casel seeks refuge with the Thierry Family, only for the Oprichnina to attack their home, forcing their daughter Sherry to help Casel escape while her parents sacrifice themselves to stop them. Sherry and Casel head to the Jade Palace, which has become the Japanese embassy, to seek asylum, as the palace is under the Rose Knights' protection and a treaty prevents the Empire from setting foot there. Despite Sherry hoping Sugawara, whom she sees as her future husband, to help them, Sugawara sticks to his country's orders to not get involved. However, when the Oprichnina arrive and arrest Casel and Sherry, Sugawara changes his mind and takes Sherry under his custody, thus starting a brutal battle between the Rose Knights and the Oprichnina. Despite what happened, Vice-Minister Shirayuri allows it and contacts her government.
21"Deadline"
The Rose Knights manage to repel the Oprichnina and free Senator Casel, but this leads to an escalation of tension between Japan and the Empire. Minister Kanou and other members of the government suggest to evacuate the Japanese delegation from the Jade Palace, but Prime Minister Morita refuses to give the green light, since representatives from other nations and the media are currently visiting the Special Region and the Alnus camp, so a demonstration of force or having no control of the situation could have bad diplomatic consequences for Japan. However, things turn bad rapidly when Zorzal has Piña under arrest for her refusal to order the Rose Knights to let his soldiers enter the palace and orders his army to put the embassy under siege, which finally drives Morita into authorizing the JSDF's deployment to evacuate the ambassadors and political refugees. Meanwhile in Rondel, Itami and the others manage to neutralize another assassination attempt against them, and prepare a plan to capture the Piper, the leader of the assassins sent to kill them.
22"The Imperial Princess in Slave's Clothing"
The Imperial Army attempts to break through the embassy are repelled by the Rose Knights, but with the massive difference in numbers it's just a matter of time until the Jade Palace's falls. Meanwhile, in Rondel, Shandy discovers that the Piper is planning another assassination attempt against Lelei, so Itami and the others prepare themselves to stop him. As expected, during Lelei's presentation, two more assassins try to kill her, but they're both thwarted by Itami and the spectators. However, at the final moment Shandy tries to stab Lelei, but is saved thanks to the armor under her dress. Interrogated about her betrayal, Shandy reveals that the Piper forced her to kill Lelei in order to save Piña, who has been formally accused of high treason. As a result, Itami and the others decide to turn back to the Imperial capital, while the JSDF prepare themselves to launch a massive operation against the capital to break the Jade Palace's siege.
23"Paradrop"
The JSDF begins their assault at the Imperial Capital, rescuing the Pro-Peace faction from prison and the Rose Knights and ambassadors from the Jade Palace. As the JSDF evacuate the refugees, Bozes and Beefeater attempt to rescue Pina from the Imperial Palace, but are forced to retreat with the evacuating JSDF due to the Imperial Army's numbers. As Itami and his group attempt to reach the capital quickly, Tyuule goads Zorzal to continue fighting as he can still employ Piña as a hostage.
24"Thus, They Fought There"
Itami and the others reach the Imperial capital, where they receive help from the rest of the 3rd Recon to rescue and escape with Piña, Hamilton and the Emperor. Meanwhile, Pina is dragged into the throne room to be judged by Zorzal for being a traitor, only to be stopped by the arrival of Itami, Lelei and Rory. Despite Zorzal having a giant Ogre fight them, the Ogre is easily killed and Zorzal is forced to give up Piña after Itami threatens to kill Zorzal if he continues harming his friends. With their targets rescued, Itami and the rest escapes from the Imperial capital and the Imperial army are destroyed by modern weapons. After recovering and realizing that Zorzal will never make peace with Japan, the Emperor decides to make Piña his heir, even though it will lead to a civil war between his children. Zorzal and his supporters are forced to leave the Imperial capital, with Zorzal vowing revenge against the Japanese and he is traumatized for life by guns. Even though achieving her goal of destroying the empire, Thule is seen crying. Ten days later in Italica, Piña is crowned as Crown Princess of the Empire, vowing to bring peace between the Empire and Japan. Itami skips Piña's coronation to attend a doujin convention, but much to his frustration Lelei, Tuka and Rory have followed him, causing a ruckus with the crowd and them being taken into protective custody by the police.

Abstract: 

This paper aims to provide a comprehensive review of the existing literature on technology-mediated goal setting (TMGS) and its impact on performance. The review will commence with a brief overview of the goal-setting theory (GST) proposed by Locke and Latham, followed by an exploration of various technological approaches that have been utilized in implementing GST, including mobile applications, social media, and gamification. Furthermore, the paper will investigate how combining multiple technological approaches to GST and introducing AI-supported algorithms can yield the best results. In conclusion, this paper will highlight the benefits and limitations of TMGS and provide recommendations for future research in this field.

Introduction:

Goal-setting is a popular strategy that has been utilized in a wide range of contexts, including education, sports, business, and personal development. The goal-setting theory (GST) developed by Locke and Latham in the 1960s posits that specific and challenging goals lead to improved performance through increased motivation and effort. Over the years, several technological approaches have been utilized in implementing GST, including mobile applications, social media, and gamification. Technology-mediated goal setting (TMGS) has the potential to provide users with personalized, real-time feedback, increase engagement and motivation, and facilitate the achievement of goals. This paper provides a comprehensive review of the existing literature on TMGS and its impact on performance. The review will explore various technological approaches that have been utilized in implementing GST, highlight the benefits and limitations of TMGS, and provide recommendations for future research in this field.

The Goal-Setting Theory:

Locke and Latham's goal-setting theory (GST) posits that specific and challenging goals lead to improved performance through increased motivation and effort. The theory suggests that goals should be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound (SMART) to be effective. The theory also emphasizes the importance of feedback in goal-setting and performance improvement. Locke and Latham proposed four mechanisms through which goal-setting affects performance: 1) directing attention, 2) mobilizing effort, 3) increasing persistence, and 4) fostering the development and use of task-relevant strategies. The theory has been widely applied in various contexts, including education, sports, business, and personal development.

Technological Approaches to Goal-Setting:

Over the years, several technological approaches have been utilized in implementing GST. These include mobile applications, social media, and gamification.

Mobile Applications:

Mobile applications (apps) have become increasingly popular as a tool for setting and achieving goals. These apps provide users with personalized, real-time feedback, reminders, and progress tracking. Some of these apps utilize the SMART framework for goal-setting, while others use other approaches. For example, the app "Habitica" utilizes gamification to incentivize users to achieve their goals. The app turns goal achievement into a game, with users earning points and rewards for completing tasks.

Social Media:

Social media platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram have also been utilized in implementing GST. Social media can be used to share goals, progress updates, and receive feedback and support from peers. Research has shown that social support can be a significant predictor of goal achievement. However, social media use can also be a distraction and lead to reduced productivity.

Gamification:

Gamification is the use of game design elements and principles in non-game contexts to motivate and engage users. Gamification has been utilized in implementing GST to incentivize users to achieve their goals. For example, the app "Fitbit" utilizes gamification to encourage users to be more physically active. The app rewards users for achieving their fitness goals and tracks their progress over time.

Combining Technological Approaches to Goal-Setting:

Recent research has shown that combining multiple technological approaches to GST can yield the best results. For example, the app "Fabulous" combines the SMART framework, gamification, and personalized coaching to help users achieve their goals. The app provides users with personalized feedback, reminders, and progress tracking, while also utilizing game design elements to incentivize users to achieve their goals.

AI-supported Algorithms:

Artificial intelligence (AI) has the potential to revolutionize TMGS. AI-supported algorithms can provide users with personalized feedback, predict potential roadblocks to goal achievement, and suggest strategies to overcome them. For example, the app "Noom" utilizes AI-supported algorithms to provide users with personalized coaching, nutrition advice, and goal tracking. The app also utilizes gamification to incentivize users to stick to their goals by providing rewards and social support. Another example is the AI-powered app "Fabulous" that uses behavioral science and personalized coaching to help users build healthy habits and achieve their goals.

One of the key benefits of AI-supported TMGS is its ability to provide personalized feedback and recommendations. Traditional goal-setting techniques often rely on generic feedback and advice that may not be relevant to the individual's unique circumstances. AI algorithms can analyze user data, such as daily activity levels, sleep patterns, and nutrition intake, to provide tailored recommendations for achieving their goals. This personalized approach can increase motivation and engagement, leading to better goal achievement outcomes.

Furthermore, AI algorithms can predict potential roadblocks to goal achievement and suggest strategies to overcome them. For example, if a user consistently misses their morning workout, an AI-powered app can suggest alternative workout times or activities that better fit the user's schedule and preferences. This proactive approach can help users stay on track and overcome obstacles that may have otherwise derailed their progress.

However, there are also limitations to AI-supported TMGS. One concern is the potential for algorithmic bias, where the algorithms may unintentionally discriminate against certain users based on their demographic or personal characteristics. Another concern is the overreliance on technology, where users may become too dependent on AI algorithms to achieve their goals, leading to a lack of self-efficacy and resilience.

Future Directions:

The existing literature on TMGS provides valuable insights into the potential benefits and limitations of utilizing technology to support goal-setting and achievement. However, there are still many areas that require further investigation.

One area for future research is the integration of multiple technological approaches to TMGS. While individual technological tools, such as mobile apps or gamification, have been shown to be effective in supporting goal achievement, combining multiple tools may yield even better results. For example, a mobile app that utilizes gamification and AI-supported algorithms may provide a more engaging and personalized experience for users, leading to better goal achievement outcomes.

Another area for future research is the long-term sustainability of TMGS. While many studies have shown short-term benefits of utilizing technology to support goal-setting and achievement, there is a lack of research on how to maintain engagement and motivation over longer periods of time. Further investigation is needed to understand how to design and implement TMGS tools that can sustain user engagement and motivation over the long term.

Finally, more research is needed to investigate the potential negative effects of TMGS. While the existing literature has primarily focused on the benefits of utilizing technology to support goal-setting and achievement, there may also be unintended consequences, such as increased stress or decreased self-efficacy, that require further investigation.

Conclusion:

Technology-mediated goal setting (TMGS) has the potential to revolutionize the way we set and achieve our goals. From mobile apps to gamification to AI-supported algorithms, there are a variety of technological approaches that can be utilized to support goal achievement. However, while the existing literature has provided valuable insights into the benefits and limitations of TMGS, there are still many areas that require further investigation.

Overall, TMGS has the potential to be a powerful tool for achieving our goals, but it is important to approach it with caution and ensure that we are utilizing it in a way that is sustainable and personalized to our unique circumstances. By continuing to research and explore the potential of TMGS, we can unlock its full potential and help individuals achieve their full potential.

Let's do some science fiction world-building and idea workshopping. The overall theme/subgenre is going to be an Ecopunk adventure, and the primary setting, at first is going to be the tidally-heated forest moon of a gas giant in a distant star system, where a colony is established, but discoveries on the moon after the establishment of the colony will make them shift their focus from colonization to conservation.

The first thing I am going to need is the big picture area where it takes place, in a sector near the base of a spiral arm in a cluster of the older range of Population I stars. This typical-for-older-pop-I, unremarkable, main sequence star is the primary of the gas giant.

The gas giant is much larger than Jupiter, and has multiple ring systems and many major moons, minor moons, and moonlets, but this particular moon is the only one with life. It skirts the snow line of the primary, spending most of its year barely outside it, and part of it barely inside it.

The life on the tidally-heated forest moon, but there is remarkably Earth-like. However, there is a near-Earth-analogue (2nd-4th planet?), in terms of size, gravity, geology, and atmosphere, in the inner system that has bizarrely alien life by Earth standards. It is also somewhat geographically unstable and has severe weather. On the initial scans and survey of the system its high ESI made it the primary object for colonization but on closer inspection it was unsuitable. 

I need a detailed, plausible astronomical/cosmological description of the system using the best models about astrophysics and planetology you have available, including all relevant stellographical data about the primary, as well as the detailed orbital data (incl. major/minor/average axis-eccentricity, tilt, inclination) for each satellite, as well as the satellites geology, atmosphere if any, hydrology if any, etc. Include features like asteroid belts and the system's outer halo of Kuiper and Oort type objects.

We can get into the specifics of the moon that will be the focus of the story later, for now, I want as much detail as possible about the system itself.

Rewrite the entire text below, make it sound more coherent and better. Mention everything in great detail, including Hadithes and Quran Verses. Be very sceptical of the author Mohammad Hijab and also add some additional good arguments:

''Hijab claims there are three different interpretations for the verse, with each referring to different anatomical features. However, these interpretations rely on ambiguous translations and cherry-picking information that best fits the intended narrative - a common strategy used to defend controversial Quranic verses. This issue is further exacerbated by the lack of clarity in the Quran itself.
The primary word in question is “sulb,” found in Quran 86:7. While Hijab claims this term can refer to various parts of the human anatomy, classical Arabic texts, such as Lane’s Lexicon, consistently define “sulb” in relation to the back. Furthermore, Quranic verses 7:172 and 6:31 use the word “thahr,” which specifically refers to the back in the context of offspring originating from it. By embracing multiple interpretations for “sulb,” Hijab is effectively disregarding the consistency and contextual usage of the term in classical texts and other Quranic verses.

The problem with the 1st interpretation is that the seminal vesicle is below the ribs and not "in between the ribs and the backbone" so it's out of the window. You literally have to draw a diagonal line from the bottom of the ribs to the bottom of the tailbone to get to the seminal vesicle. Even so, it's not the actual fluid that gives rise to a new human. That's the sperm and it is produced in the testes of a male after puberty, not in the embryonic stage so where the gonads originally were during pregnancy is irrelevant

Hijab’s attempt to connect this verse with modern scientific understanding falls short as he relies on Bucaille and Giraud’s claims that “tara’ib” refers to the female sexual anatomy. Critics have debunked this view, arguing that there is no strong evidence to support such an interpretation, and that this claim simply advances a narrative that aligns with modern knowledge.
The comparison between the processes of human reproduction presented in Quran 86:7 and the theories of Galen, a Greek physician from the 2nd century CE, serves to discredit any claims of miraculous scientific accuracy. Considering that these ideas existed long before the advent of Islam, it is questionable how Hijab’s arguments could serve as a testament to the divine nature of the Quran.
By taking a closer look at Quranic verses and Hadiths, it is evident that the interpretations Hijab proposes simply reinforce a narrative that is aligned with modern scientific understanding. However, these explanations rest on ambiguous translations and cherry-picked evidence, rendering them unconvincing. Thus, the attempts to reconcile Quran 86:7 with scientific knowledge, like Hijab’s arguments, ultimately prove insufficient in addressing the skepticism surrounding the supposed divine origin of the Quran.

86:5. "Now let man but think from what he is created! He is created from a drop emitted. Proceeding from between the backbone and the ribs."

First it should be noted that the above passage is not poetic. In its context 86:5 lists a variety of natural wonders which are given as a "sign" of God's goodness for all men to see. With that in mind the author of the above passage from the Quran tells us that sperm (drop emitted) comes from the area of the body "between the backbone and the ribs." In actuality, sperm is produced and stored in the scrotum; more technically, in the system of tubes in the testicles which are located in the scrotum. The scrotum is not located between the back and the ribs. (If yours is, contact us and we'll refer you so somebody.) Can the Quran be the Word of God and be wrong about reproduction, which God created?

Human Reproduction
23:14. "Then We made the sperm into a clot of congealed blood, then of that clot we made a lump; then We made out of that lump bones and clothed the bones with flesh; the We developed out of it another creature."

There are four orders of error in this small passage. However, it is no fault of Mohammad, he did not have the technology available to discover the thruth about embriology through observation.

1st error � "congealed blood." The cells which begin to form blood, much less clotting agents, do not begin formation until the fourth week of pregnancy. After the joining of the sperm and egg into a morula, there is not blood or clotting agent yet in formation.

2nd error � "clot." This is mentioned as an additional error since the concept of a clot or collection of blood cells is implied twice in this short passage.

3rd and 4th errors � "bones." The roder presented in the Quran is fertilization, blood (or cell) formation, bones, then flesh. This is untrue. Organs and flesh are actually the first that begin cellular divsion and formation. Later, as the child grows, bone structures begin to develop along with organs and flesh.

Any of these, and the other readily available facts regarding human reproduction can be looked up in an encyclopedia and compared with the Quran. Can the Quran be the Word of God and be wrong about reproduction, which God created?

1)
The verse refers to fluid and not sperm, and the fluid comes from between the backbone or loins and the ribs. Even if the Qur’ān were referring to sperm, the sperm is created in the testes which are located between the loins and the ribs.


2)
The verse refers to the baby emerging from the mother’s womb, which is located between the backbone or loins and the ribs.

3)
The verse refers to the man and woman engaged in sexual intercourse, by which the ejaculatory fluid is issued between them during intercourse.''

. Kohta replaces Keita Aono, the protagonist of Betterman. Kaede, his childhood friend and also the psychotic serial killer known as Lucy, replaces both Hinoki Sai from Betterman and Rei Ayanami from Evangelion.

. Mamoru Amani was created as a result of an attempt by NERV to restart PROJECT NET which they had initially collaborated with the Amagi Corporation to initiate as an attempt to create the perfect human to pilot the EVA Units, instead of being a refugee from the Green Planet of the Trinary Solar System like in the GaoGaiGar canon.

. Galeon is an experimental combat mech created by NERV and EVOL just before the creation of Jin Kanzaki and Kaede from the technology retrieved from the ancestral race which created the Angels, instead of being an extraterrestrial combat unit created by Cain. 

. Jin Kanzaki was kidnapped by agents of EVOL and forced to pilot EVA-Unit 01 under the name Shinji Ikari, due to Gendo Ikari's assumption that he was the NERV commander's missing son. . When fleeing Tokyo-3 after the massacre at the Amagi conference center, Jin encounters Michiku and the Earth Defense Brigade Gutsy Geoid Guard fighting off a horde of Players unleashed upon the city by the sinister de-facto leader of EVOL Seiji Haytani and reluctantly helps them defeat the monsters and save the city. Jin manages to escape after this and make his way to a bus heading towards Kamakura, but Michiru is able to sense him and wonders who exactly was this mysterious vigilante with powers so similar to hers. 

. At Kamakura, Jin lodges at the Maple Inn and quickly adjusts to life in the country as he tries to figure out what to do with his life, sneaking out of the hotel at nights to keep his vigilante skills sharp and control his transformaton into ZET. 

.Meanwhile, Kohta forms a harem with Kaede, Yuka, his younger sister Kanae who is also a diclonius, the younger diclonii Nana and Mariko, and the orphan girl Mayu after the girls confront him and reveal the true extent of their feelings for him.

. Jin's antics in Kamakura reach the ears of the Institute, which is under the impression that Lucy is causing trouble after the escape from the facility.

. The psychotic ex-ROKAF [Republic of Korea Armed Forces] commando turned elite SAT operative Bando meets Jin instead of Kaede/"Lucy"/Nyu and is brutally thrashed by the Black Sweeper, with the Institute being barely able to save Bando's life. 

. Meanwhile, Michiku and her family head to Kamakura on vacation, staying at the Maple Inn as well due to the Amani family being a sub-branch of Kohta's family and the Amagis. Kaede and Yuka immediately sense that the serious and determined, but also chipper and happy young girl staying at the Inn with her family is a diclonius like them, although Kaede is confused as to why she also senses the same spark of divinity that she herself has due to her status as an artificial angel inside of Michiku. 

. Jin discovers Kaede's diclonius nature after she uses her vectors to clean up a room when she thinks no one is looking, and also discovers that Yuka and Kanae are diclonii as well. He keeps this information to himself and continues trying to stay under the radar and master his powers. 

. Meanwhile, Michiku discovers that Jin was the mysterious vigilante who helped her and the Gutsy Geoid Guard stop the Players in Tokyo-3 and confronts him, revealing that she also has the ability to transform into ZET. With the threat of the Institute looming, Jin reluctantly agrees to help Michiku. 

. During Lucy's confrontation with the SAT team sent to kill her, Jin discovers the location of the Institute and manages to sneak in, gathering evidence of its horrendous experiments on innocent girls and young women who just happened to be born as diclonii before making his escape. He reports this information to Michiku, who contacts the GGG. The GGG then send in a strike team to wipe out the Institute.

. The story ends with Kaede celebrating the destruction of the Institute, which is stated in the local news as a result of the flooding of a nearby island. She begins to hug Kohta and cry upon his shoulder, which causes the other girls to jump Kohta as well. Jin shakes his head at this and comments that Kohta and the girls of his harem are probably going to be parents very soon, only to see Mamoru blushing in embarrassment as she looks at the girls showing their love for Kohta. 

Jin then sighs and takes a sip of his coffee, knowing that Mamoru will most likely join Kohta's harem as well.

Here is a film scene:
"INT. HOSPITAL ROOM - DAY

Solange lies in her hospital bed, looking pale but still radiating an air of confidence and elegance despite her recent amputations. She talks to herself in a calm manner, planning her future life with a touch of somber humor.

SOLANGE: (to herself) Well, Solange, my dear, looks like you won't be running any marathons anymore. But that's okay. You can still do plenty of other things. Like...like being a motivational speaker! Yes, that's it. You can inspire people with your story and show them that even without legs, life goes on.

Dr. Bends enters the room, his imposing figure looming over Solange's bedside. He checks her chart and nods to himself before turning his attention to Solange.

DR. BENDS: Good morning, Miss Ancel. How are we feeling today?

SOLANGE: (smirking) Oh, just peachy, Doctor. Just peachy.

DR. BENDS: (smiling wryly) Glad to hear that. Now, let's take a look at those leg stumps of yours.

Solange winces as Dr. Bends examines her legs, his fingers probing the sensitive skin around the amputation sites.

SOLANGE: (gritting her teeth) So, Doctor, tell me something. Why did you amputate my right leg? It didn't seem nearly as bad as my left one.

DR. BENDS: (looking up from his work) Ah, yes. The eternal question. Why indeed?

He leans against the bed, a thoughtful expression on his face.

DR. BENDS: (nonchalantly) To be honest, Miss Ancel, I'm not entirely sure it needed to be amputated. Your left leg, well, that was a lost cause. But the right one...it could have gone either way.

SOLANGE: (surprised) What? Then why did you do it?

DR. BENDS: (shrugging) Utilitarianism, my dear. Simple as that. Better safe than sorry. And let's be real, you're young, you'll adapt. Besides...(he pauses, eyeing Solange's body) you're quite the looker. I figured you'd manage just fine without legs.

Solange's eyes narrow, her face twisting into a mixture of anger and disgust.

SOLANGE: (bitterly) That's your reasoning? You took away my legs because you think I'm pretty? Because you think I'll 'manage just fine' without them? Are you kidding me?

DR. BENDS: (unfazed) No, no, no. Don't misunderstand me. It's nothing personal. I simply believe that, all things considered, you'll make do. Life isn't always fair, Miss Ancel. Sometimes tough decisions need to be made.

SOLANGE: (outraged) Tough decisions? You call cutting off someone's limbs without their consent a 'tough decision'? You're sick, Doctor. Sick and twisted.

Dr. Bends chuckles, unperturbed by Solange's accusations.

DR. BENDS: (leaning closer) Oh, come now. Don't be so dramatic. You're alive, aren't you? That's what matters. The rest is just details.

Dr. Bends straightens up, his expression stern.

DR. BENDS: (authoritatively) Enough. I've heard enough. You're lucky to be alive, Miss Ancel. Remember that. And don't bother trying to sue me; you won't find a lawyer crazy enough to take your case.

With that parting shot, Dr. Bends exits the room, leaving Solange seething in frustration and indignation."

The study of child narrators and focalisers increasingly popular in recent years (twenty-first century).  observed in the growing number of publications and scholarly works that have emerged 
Novels for adults about childhood are a booming genre within the contemporary literary market

Your suggestions highlight some of the significant challenges and potential solutions for a long-duration interstellar probe. Let’s address these two main concerns: protection against micrometeoroids and space debris, and the idea for an innovative propulsion system that utilizes interstellar medium.

1. Anti-Particular Impactor System (APIS):
- The concept of an APIS could involve an advanced sensory array to detect incoming micrometeoroids and space debris well in advance. This could combine radar, LIDAR, or other forms of detection.
- AI would process the data in real-time to predict the trajectory of potential impactors and calculate evasive maneuvers.
- The spacecraft could be equipped with a propulsion system capable of making rapid, precise adjustments to its trajectory to avoid collisions.
- For very small particles that are numerous and hard to detect individually, the craft might include shielding, such as a Whipple shield (multilayered impact protection), or an electromagnetic shield to deflect charged particles.

2. Propulsion System Utilizing Interstellar Gas:
- The concept of a propulsion system that collects and utilizes interstellar gas is reminiscent of the Bussard Ramjet, a theoretical idea proposed in the 1960s by physicist Robert W. Bussard. In this concept, a spacecraft would use a large magnetic field to collect hydrogen from the interstellar medium and use it in a fusion reactor to propel the spacecraft.
- While the idea is fascinating, there are substantial technical challenges to overcome, such as the collection of sufficient fuel, the efficiency of the fusion process, and the generation of a magnetic field large enough to function effectively.
- Development of such a system would require breakthroughs in controlled nuclear fusion technology, materials science, and magnetic field generation.
- Additionally, the low density of the interstellar medium poses a challenge, as the amount of hydrogen available for collection is sparse, and the efficiency of the fusion process must be extremely high to be practical.

Implementing an APIS and developing a propulsion system that could utilize interstellar gas would be groundbreaking advancements in space exploration. However, these concepts are still largely theoretical and would require considerable research and development.

It’s worth mentioning that integrating such advanced systems into a spacecraft would significantly increase its complexity, and by extension, the potential points of failure. A rigorous design, extensive testing, and the inclusion of redundancy would be crucial to ensure mission success.

The concepts you propose sit at the cutting edge of speculative technology and, while they are not part of our current capabilities, they represent the kind of forward-thinking required to push the boundaries of space exploration further into the interstellar domain. Researchers and engineers continue to explore these and other ideas to meet the challenges of navigating and surviving in the vast expanse of space.

Utilizing a 100km-long structure attached to a spacecraft as both a particle collector and a communication antenna is indeed a bold and imaginative concept. Spacecraft already use long antennas for communication with Earth, but these are typically on a much smaller scale. Let’s examine the potential of such a concept:

1. Antenna Length and Signal Strength:
- The length of an antenna is closely related to the wavelength of the signals it can efficiently transmit and receive. Longer antennas can be more effective for certain types of low-frequency communication, which can travel great distances.
- A very long antenna could potentially enhance the spacecraft’s ability to communicate over vast interstellar distances. This could be crucial for maintaining contact with a probe traveling several parsecs (tens of light-years) from Earth.

2. Mechanical Challenges:
- Constructing and deploying a 100km-long structure in space presents significant engineering challenges. The structure must be lightweight yet strong enough to withstand the rigors of space travel, including the forces exerted on it during maneuvers and the stresses of the space environment.
- Attitude control and stabilization of the spacecraft would become more complex with such a long appendage, as any movement could induce vibrations or oscillations.

Incorporating a robotic “crabbie fellow” repair drone into the design of an advanced spacecraft is indeed a creative and potentially very effective idea. This concept suggests a level of autonomy and adaptability that could significantly extend the operational lifespan of a spacecraft. Here’s a closer look at how such an in-space repair system could work:

1. Robotic Repair Drone (“Crabbie Fellow”):
- The drone could be designed with multiple articulated limbs for maneuvering on the exterior of the spacecraft, performing inspections, diagnostics, and repairs.
- It would be equipped with tools and sensors to address a variety of potential issues, such as patching micro-meteorite damage, fixing loose components, or cleaning and maintaining surface instruments.

2. AI Integration:
- The repair drone could have its own AI system for complex tasks, allowing it to solve unforeseen problems creatively and make autonomous decisions when necessary.
- Alternatively, it could be remotely controlled or guided by the spacecraft’s main AI, operating as an extension of the larger system.

3. Emergency Propulsion:
- In case the drone drifts away from the spacecraft, it would have a small propulsion system, possibly cold gas thrusters or ionic mechanisms, which would enable it to return safely.
- The drone’s AI would be responsible for calculating the correct thrust and trajectory to re-dock with the spacecraft.

4. Storage and Deployment:
- A dedicated repair bay within the spacecraft would protect the drone from the harsh space environment when not in use and allow for easy deployment when needed.
- The bay could have mechanisms to recharge the drone’s power supply and restock any consumables used during repairs.

5. Safety and Redundancy:
- The drone would need to operate with high reliability, so redundant systems for critical components would be essential.
- A tether or magnetic anchoring system could provide extra security to prevent the drone from straying too far during operations.

6. Machine Learning:
- Integration of machine learning could enable the drone to improve its repair methods over time based on past experience and data.

The “crabbie fellow” repair drone adds an element of whimsy to the concept, but the underlying idea of an autonomous repair mechanism is a serious consideration for long-duration space missions. It reflects the trend in space systems towards autonomy, in-situ resource utilization, and the need for self-sufficiency as missions venture farther from Earth and beyond immediate human assistance.

Whether for use in Earth orbit, deep space, or even interstellar missions, such technologies may become crucial for the success and longevity of future space exploration efforts. Creating a team of specialized “crabbie fellow” repair drones of varying sizes that emerge from the spacecraft structure to perform different tasks is an intriguing idea that draws inspiration from swarm robotics and modular systems. Each drone could be specialized for certain functions, from macro-scale repairs to micro-scale precision work.

Here are some considerations for such a system:

1. Diversity in Functionality:
- Larger drones could handle big tasks like structural repairs or moving larger components.
- Smaller drones could be designed for detailed work, like repairing or recalibrating sensitive instruments or sealing small leaks.

2. Self-Replicating Drones:
- The concept of self-replicating robots is an advanced idea in robotics referred to as “von Neumann probes,” after mathematician John von Neumann who theorized about self-replicating systems.
- Self-replication would require the drones to have the ability to gather and process raw materials, manufacture parts, and assemble them into new drones.
- This capability could allow for a sustainable fleet of repair drones, but it would necessitate a reliable source of materials and an extremely sophisticated level of automation.

3. Resource Management:
- The drones would need access to raw materials to support self-replication. These could be sourced from collected space debris or the interstellar medium, but refining usable materials from such sources would be highly challenging.
- Alternatively, the spacecraft could carry a stockpile of raw materials specifically for drone replication, but this would add mass to the initial launch.

4. Risk Mitigation:
- As you mentioned, malfunctioning AI could lead to unintended consequences, such as drones disassembling the spacecraft or replicating uncontrollably (“grey goo” scenario).
- To prevent such outcomes, fail-safes, checks and balances, and strict replication protocols would need to be in place. AI systems would require rigorous testing, validation, and layers of redundancy.

5. Collaboration and Communication:
- The swarm of drones would need to communicate and collaborate effectively, potentially using AI to allocate tasks, manage resources, and solve complex problems as a collective rather than as individuals.

While having a group of self-replicating repair drones enables resilience and adaptability, their development presents substantial challenges in robotics, materials science, and AI. Current state-of-the-art technology has yet to reach the level of sophistication required for the real-world implementation of self-replicating robots, especially in the space environment where conditions are more punishing, and resources are scarce.

Ethical considerations would also be paramount, as the ability to self-replicate is a powerful capability that should be approached with caution to avoid unintended ecological or safety risks.

Nevertheless, swarm robotic systems and modular drones are active areas of research, and many of the foundational technologies for such concepts are being developed and tested in terrestrial contexts. These may eventually be adapted for space applications, leading to smarter, more resilient, and increasingly autonomous spacecraft.

Indeed, the notion of self-replicating spacecraft remains firmly in the realm of science fiction, as does the idea of advanced AI evolving over the course of an interstellar journey spanning parsecs. Both concepts are frequently explored in speculative fiction and futurism due to their intriguing implications and the philosophical questions they raise about the future of technology and exploration.

In considering these ideas:

1. Self-Replication: This idea extends from the concept of von Neumann probes, which are theoretical self-replicating spacecraft that could potentially explore and colonize the galaxy by creating copies of themselves from local resources. Despite being a fascinating concept, the technical challenges and ethical considerations, including the potential for uncontrolled replication, make it a currently unattainable technology.

2. AI Evolution: Over long space voyages, AI would need to handle operations and respond to unforeseen challenges, potentially learning and adapting over time. The AI could theoretically evolve within the parameters of its programming and learning capabilities.  On December 3, 1984 Dragon Ball's Sun Goku was introduced to the public, and over the last 35 years has become one of the most recognizable and prolific characters of the modern age. From TV shows to commercials to blockbuster movies, from video games to parades to being the mascot for the 2020 Olympic Games, you would assume for one to accrue such incredible success, said character would need to be widely accepted as a good one, or at least a well-written one. However, nowadays there's a strongly held belief that if a character doesn't develop or grow from an experience, then that character in question is a poorly written one. Therefore to test this theory, a while back I posted a poll on my Twitter asking the question, if given the choice between Goku and Vegeta, who'd you prefer, and why? The one that was close with over 4,000 votes cast Vegeta 1. With the majority of people who voted for Vegeta bolstering their choice by arguing, Vegeta has grown and changed a considerable amount over his character arc. Goku has no arc. He remains the same. While most of the statement is technically correct, this led me to believe that on a fundamental narrative level, the character of Sun Goku is deeply misunderstood by an enormous portion of the viewership because Goku does have a character arc. He is a terrific example of what writers call the Flat Character arc. In 2016, KM Wild and Publisha Book called, Create and Character arcs, in which she describes three character arc methods. The Positive Character arc? This is the most common character arc found in fiction where the character undergoes a positive change. The Negative Character arc, where the character undergoes a negative change, and finally, the Flat Character arc, which we will be discussing in this video. In order to make sense of the Flat Character arc, it's important to understand the most common arc in storytelling first. The Positive Character arc, in which the character and question spends their entire journey overcoming a specific lie they hold to be true, Wild and calls this script writing trope. The lie the character believes. A wonderful example of this positive character arc is observed with the character of Vegeta. For his entire existence, Vegeta has been someone who believed that power was the only important thing in life. And to pursue anything else would be a fool's errand. This was the lie Vegeta believed. And throughout his life, this lie was reinforced by the world around him. Through pursuing this end, Vegeta sacrificed his everything to achieve his goal. It's his belief in this lie that leads him to die on planet Namik. When faced with the reality his choices have led him to, he crumbles, and ultimately falls. Vegeta's lie was that he believed the only value to be found in life was through the pursuit of power. And his arc was about the journey he took in order to overcome this lie and to embrace what was actually true. To find value in those he loved. And in that moment the viewer and Vegeta share a much-needed catharsis. As while in writes, the Positive Character arc is about the lie the character believes, which he will spend the entire journey overcoming. However, unlike the Positive Character arc which tells the story based on a lie the character believes, the flat character arc is about the truth the character believes. In the flat character arc the protagonist already has a handle on what the truth is. And he will use that truth to overcome the challenges of the plot. And probably to transform a lie-burdened world. One of the defining features of the flat arc is that the character begins his journey to already believing in a certain truth. So in Goku is an enthusiastic, innocent and motivated person who believes that he can always be better today than he is tomorrow. And not in a diminishing or deprecating way he thrives annoying he can be better tomorrow than he is today. And these ideals have not changed since he was first introduced to us in the mid-80s. To help prove that I'm not making these points up, here are some other characters that fit this mold too. Forced Gun is an honest, compassionate and determined individual who wants to find and be with the person he loves, Jenny, and from the beginning of the film to the end his outlook on life never falters reflected in the famous quote, Life is like a box of chocolates. You never know what you're going to get until you take that first bite. Indiana Jones is a determined and courageous man who believes in doing what is right. From the outset these are what his ideals are and what makes his story compelling isn't how he changes but how the world around him reacts to these characteristics he possesses. The titan is an infinitely powerful otherwise ordinary guy with strong morals and ideals for what he thinks a hero should be, bored by conventional crime fighting he earns for the thrill of a real challenge. And despite never actually getting that, his personality and ideals don't waver. He is human but he is also a real hero. What I find personally interesting about all of these characters is, none of them are really praised or remembered for being great characters. Instead people will often say, for a scum is an amazing movie, or that one punchman was a great TV series. However a fundamental difference between for a scum but one punchman is that one is a movie and the other is a television show. Rarely will you see someone say that the character for a scum is a bad one but people will flat out dismiss one punchman on its main character as very premise alone. Personally I think the length of a TV series versus a movie plays a large factor here. People expect a desire a TV shows characters to grow and develop over the series in order to justify its long length. Specific emphasis is put on shows like Dragon Ball, Naruto or One Piece because their theme is sent around self-improvement. Whereas in a film it's not as noticeable if their characters don't develop over the course of its runtime. If we look closely at the character of Sun Goku, we observe from the very beginning of the show, his character is fundamentally at odds with the story and world around. This is a writing technique specifically used for characters that utilize a flat arc and so while Goku himself believes the truth from the outset, pretty much all those he interacts with believes a lot and the intrigue for the journey comes from Goku's sensibilities changing the world around him for the better. For example, this is a very important thing. Or if you want an even earlier example, here's this. Despite Master Oshih having taken a considerable amount of his life to perfect the Kamehameha, Goku managed to learn it with relative ease. However the most noticeable example of Goku changing the world around him using the truth he has is right here. On top of changing the world around him, he also changes the supporting cast for the better too. The characters like Master Oshih are now retired because Goku is now the new savior of the earth. Characters like Ten Shinhan, Piccolo and Vegeta have changed from bad to good because of his actions. The reason why Goku remains the focus of Dragon Ball is due to one simple fact. Goku is Dragon Ball. Everything that happens in Dragon Ball is due to this character and it can't be any other way. So let me explain why. Goku's character is ideal for a long running show because unlike Vegeta and Piccolo, his arc doesn't have an expiry date. Vegeta's character was praised in its climax, but because the show wanted to continue, his development had to be altered and slightly red-cut at the beginning of Dragon Ball super. During which they had to repeat certain key scenes to invoke a similar reaction from the fanbase. The same we said for Piccolo, jumping in front of Gohan blocking a blast during the resurrection F arc, it's just not the same because as the show reflects, his time in the sun is over. On a much more real level, Gohan's story is absolutely over. It ended itself. That was the coming of age moment and nothing he can do will ever top that. Unless they drastically revamped, reinvent or retcon his character. But unlike Vegeta, Piccolo and Gohan, Goku is not restricted by such conventions due to the nature of his story arc. Because Goku doesn't need to change or grow from an experience, the intrigue when he interacts with a character or situation comes from how the world or that character reacts to Goku. So technically, Goku and characters like Goku that implement the flat arc have as much intrigue as the world around them does. And as I'm sure many writers would tell you, it's much easier to create interesting tasks and worlds for Goku to explore than it would be for someone to write another way for Vegeta to swallow his pride and for us to care about it. The point that I'm trying to make here is, despite his unwavering sensibilities, Goku has remained engaging throughout. Specifically when he is written by a curatorial Yamaha, who understood that the character of Goku needed to have a flat arc if he wanted to have the flexibility to write a week to week manga chapter. Goku is a flexible engaging character because he utilizes the flat character arc. And that is why this particular arc has value. And so with the stigma nowadays claiming that Goku is a boring character because he has no personal development, I feel compelled to say, no, that's not a fair assessment at all. On top of the positive character arc being the most common arc in character writing, and one of the most noticeable, it also seems to be the only one given any spotlight at all. Rarely does someone talk about a negative character arc which would be observed with characters like Yagami from Death Note or even Zamasu from Dragon Ball Super. This is when a character goes from a good or benign standing to that of a villain or changes for the worse. Even a flat arc like Goku's can be subdivided into categories, Goku is a positive flat arc. And an example of a negative flat arc can be observed with characters like Freeze, who are evil to the core, unwavering, manipulating the world around them instead of the world changing them. One of the reason why Freeze and Goku's interactions are so compelling, because they are both steadfast in their beliefs. I am certainly not trying to claim that one character arc is superior to the other, but merely pointing out certain advantages the flat arc might have over the others because of its design. So just to reiterate, Dragon Ball cannot be Dragon Ball without Goku. And while wonderful characters like Piccolo and Vegeta are thrilling and fun to watch, I think it's important to acknowledge that Goku's character has value 2, but in a vastly different way.
